media:group.media:title: the existence forecast
media:group.media:description:
cloudy with a chance of being. (more silliness below)
My stuff: Books what I wrote yo ► https://www.amazon.com/Exurb1a/e/B06XFM14M8/ For sending personalised insults ► https://www.facebook.com/exurb1a/ T-shirts, mugs, and sadness ► https://teespring.com/stores/exurb1a I also make horrendous music ► https://soundcloud.com/exurbia-1 Help me to do this full-time if you're deranged enough (and thank you kindly) ► https://www.patreon.com/exurb1r?ty=h
It's almost impossible to know how many species are going extinct in a given time without being sure how many species there actually are on the planet - which we're not. The 150 species per day figure was suggested at the UN Convention on Biological Diversity and it sounded suitably horrible so in the figure went.

A new book will be out in the next few months – not depressing sci-fi for once – and more stuff is coming, promise. If that's something you're waiting for, then thank you kindly for waiting. I know I said it'd only be a little while, but I suppose 6 months is a little while for cosmic bodies like stars or deities. If you don't know what Geometry for Ocelots is, please ignore this message and I hope you're having an adequate day.
Vaguely related mystery link: https://youtu.be/Q34z5dCmC4M

media:group.media:title: 8 Million Species of Aliens
media:group.media:description:
I think therefore I bork. *the adverb mention is just straight up wrong. "F-ing unhinged" is still an adjective. Excuse my silliness. (More things to waste your time with below.)
The grammatical variations of a certain f-word were of course yoinked from George Carlin's bit which did it better: (Seems to be George Carlin originally anyway.) https://youtu.be/xZkb4TPI-Lo
The mention about toile and toilet was put extremely badly. "Toilette" was the diminutive, not the other way around as poor wording implied.
There's some controversy surrounding how efficient a bee's waggle dance actually is. I'm no apiologist (no seriously, that's a specialist of bee science), but the problem doesn't seem to bee (heh) with the waggle dance. Rather, the dispute is over how much of a difference it makes to bees watching the dance itself. For 1000x more depth than this video went into: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3153927/
One of the opening slides shows the greatest copypasta known to humankind: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/navy-seal-copypasta
The "If this little lion could speak..." line is lifted almost directly from Wittgenstein. The original line is "If a lion could speak, we could not understand him." As in: even *with* complex language, alien minds might still be incomprehensible.
Quite a lot of the silliness with English was taken from John McWhorter's brilliant Our Magnificent Bastard Tongue: The Untold History of English. It's a great read: https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/3143472-our-magnificent-bastard-tongue
This one was largely inspired by a friend trying to convince me that animals don't just have a 'smaller' form of human intelligence, they've gone off in other evolutionary directions and we should probably count those different types of smarts as valid too. So, thank you to HF for that.
The thumbnail is an axolotl, and just in case you haven't come across them yet they're quite fantastic: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axolotl
The Cephalotes Varians ant photo has been used with a commercial license courtesy of smugmug.com
Bonus fun: I spent about a month trying to come up with the title for this one. "The Tower of Babble" seemed like a fun comedy twist on the biblical story. I looked it up. No one seemed to have used it already. Well, I felt terribly proud of that and walked with a spring in my step for several weeks. Just before uploading today I thought I'd check again. I hadn't noticed Google was kindly correcting the typo for me. Of course The Tower of Babble is already a thing; books, films, podcasts. Almost threw myself out the window.

entry.title: There's No Such Thing As Orange

I made this one after years of getting stuck in debates with people about stuff I changed my mind about only a year later, and regretted being so adamant that tabasco is disgusting or whatever. (It’s not, it’s amazing.) We’re clearly not going to solve the problems in the centuries ahead with compassion alone. But we could sure end the world without it.

media:group.media:title: The Rememberer
media:group.media:description:
I’m sure we’ve all been through that phase when you just want to make 30 minute thinly veiled monochrome allegories about your fear of ageing. Books what I wrote, yo ► https://tinyurl.com/ycnl5bo3
Bonus trivia: This video is not finished. But if I don’t let it go now, I will be. The beginning fell into my head several months ago. I assumed it would take a few weeks to make, at most. Little did I know it would sprout multiple heads and take over my life for two and a half months. If you didn’t enjoy watching it, take comfort that I didn’t enjoy making it. (Just jokez. Thanks for watching my stuff as always, and hope you’re well :) )
Bonus bonus trivia: The original title was supposed to be "The Nine Isles of Neverdead", but google told me Neverdead is already a thing; apparently a video game about demons and stuff.
I'm sorry this one took a while. I'm especially sorry to folks on Patreon. I think I told you it would only be another week about three weeks ago? Apologies, but I didn't want to put the thing out half baked.
A very, very big thank you to a friend who wishes to go by the name Jimmy Cakeshoes. When the editing was almost done, it was impossible to render the video because my PC kept having little meltdowns and locking up. One genius technical fix later from Dr. Cakeshoes and all was well. Big love to you, man.
The poems mentioned at the end are:
The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock by T. S. Eliot https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poetrymagazine/poems/44212/the-love-song-of-j-alfred-prufrock
The Rime of the Ancient Mariner by Samuel Taylor Coleridge https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/43997/the-rime-of-the-ancient-mariner-text-of-1834
Kubla Khan also by Samuel Taylor Coleridge https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/43991/kubla-khan
I fully admit to stealing that line from the end of The Great Gatsby.

entry.title: The Moon is a Door to Forever

media:group.media:title: The Moon is a Door to Forever
media:group.media:description:
So let’s go back, eh? Books what I wrote, yo ► https://tinyurl.com/ycnl5bo3 More spacey stuff and some recommendations below ►
Enormous liberties have been taken with this one; some of the footage isn’t from Apollo 11 (the mission we chat about here), but subsequent missions to the moon. Footage was really quite difficult to find, so hopefully you can forgive me playing a little visually loose with the truth.
Also the Soviet space program was barely even mentioned in the video. I’ve often thought it’s a bit sad that the Soviet Union got the first satellite into space, the first doggos (let’s not discuss it), the first man, the first woman, the first probe to the moon, the first spacewalk, and the first robot on another celestial body – yet the winner’s medal generally goes to the US for reaching the moon, and doing it so brilliantly. (Which they did, and which it was.)
Not in any way meaning to discredit the US here, I’d just like to urge you to spare a thought for those other clever men and women a continent away who were – at the very same time – also taking marvellous and brave strides into space.
I’ve had quite a fascination with the Apollo program over the years, and space in general. If it’s something you’re interested in too, here’s the stuff I really, really enjoyed reading and watching. (No one’s paying me for this, I just dig them. The audiobook versions are great too.)
Mike Massimino - Spaceman https://www.amazon.com/Spaceman-Astronauts-Unlikely-Journey-Universe-ebook/dp/B01A4B1SK0
Robert Kurson - Rocket Men: The Daring Odyssey of Apollo 8 and the Astronauts Who Made Man's First Journey to the Moon https://www.amazon.com/Rocket-Men-Odyssey-Astronauts-Journey/dp/B075H2P225/ref=sr_1_2keywords=apollo+8&qid=1581704489&s=digital-text&sr=1-2
Andrew Smith - Moondust: In Search of the Men Who Fell to Earth https://www.amazon.com/Moondust-Search-Men-Fell-Earth/dp/0007155425
Apollo 11 https://www.imdb.com/title/tt8760684/
In the Shadow of the Moon (THE DOCUMENTARY, NOT THE OTHER ONE) https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0925248/
Before uploading this video I had a fairly long conversation with a meme-knowledgeable friend about whether dabbing would be appropriate in a thumbnail. I wasn’t sure what dabbing is.
She assured me that since an astronaut’s doing it, it’s fine.
